reviewTitle: The best way to get around Bangkok. But can get very full
reviewText: I have been using the sky train for 17 years since it first opened  It is the only way to get around Sukhumvit road area in a hurry unless you want to risk a motorbike taxi experience   However do avoid peak times if you are a tourist and have a choice  From 430 pm heading south east to upper sukhumvit you may have trouble getting on I have waited for 3 trains before now   Once in do expect to get very friendly with everyone as they squeeze you on like sardines in a tin   They run more frequently at these times but in my mind should also increase the carriages too   Other peak times at weekends in early evenings heading to lower Sukhumvit can also be challenge as the residents head for nights out   Otherwise it's the best way to get around Bangkok   It's more convenient to change at Asok for the underground if heading to Chatuchak  market However BTS Mo Chit station is only a few minutes walk to the market and also no issue   The skywalks are a pleasant addition over the years keeping you above the roads and away from the chaos below   I fully recommend getting a rabbit card per person even if you only here for a few days it saves so much time at the stations queuing for change and tickets  As well at Siam Square the queues for tickets can be up to 30 minutes in the busy times  Rabbit cards are easy to get at any station and can be refunded if you don't use it all  Never put more than 500 THB in case you lose it Average journey cost is anyway only 30 50 baht So you can work it out easy
Can't really go wrong with the BTS to get around Bangkok It's cheap and simple to use can get busy at times but they do come regularly
If you are not a fan of tuk tuk or finding tuktuk is weird then BTS is for you Taking a cab in BKK is pain in the butt sometimes as the traffic congestion is terrible

reviewTitle: Skytrain easy to use and regular
reviewText: The Skytrain is clean regular and around ¬£1 (40 Baht) for a single journey Queues for a ticket only take a couple of minutes there are machines but I think they only take coins As a family of four we used the Skytrain for several days without issue but we then found that we could usually get a taxi for less money as there were 4 of us this would not be the case with smaller groups

Once you get used to it the BTS skytrain is really easy to use if you are travelling a lot you can get a day pass unsure on price but cheap   The staff talk good English but you need to be patient sometimes The train is nice and clean sometimes cleaner than the UK trains I would easily recommend to anyone looking for a cheaper alternative to a taxi or tuk tuk

reviewTitle: Amazing and efficient method of travel!
reviewText: The BTS Skytrain is both an efficient and convenient way to travel around Bangkok It can get crowded in the mornings and evenings but there is usually room to go where I am trying to go Make sure you have change and know where the stop you want to go to I love that they have maps showing the next stops by the stairs up to the platform because it has saved me many times from being on the side going the direction opposite to the one I want to go When in Bangkok this is the only way to get around the Sukhumvit and Silom areas

reviewText: I am staying Near Nana BTS in Sukhumvit road and for me Sky train has been a good way to get around the major shopping malls So you don't have to get a card you can simply purchase paper tickets at the station it can cost up from 25 to 50 Bhat for one way ticket depending on your destination You might as well use google to find your interchange The lines to purchase tickets can be pretty long in the evening so when you board the train in the morning do get the return tickets as well which will save you time in the evening Sometimes it can be difficult to keep track of the stations so keep an eye on the station names at the top of doorways But station names are mentioned in English so there should not be much of a problem   Bangkok is shoppers paradise so when you book you hotels do book it near BTS stations

reviewTitle: Great Way To Get Around Central Bangkok
reviewText: The BTS skytrain is a great way to get around central Bangkok And it's expanding it's reach to outer Bangkok During peak times it's pretty crowded especially if you have to buy a ticket before you get on That's why I recommend buying a multiple trip ticket if you're going to be here for very long then you avoid at least one line The train takes you to many of the main places that you want to get to in Bangkok And if you use it in conjunction with the MTR (subway) and Rail Link to Suvarnabhumi airport you can get around to even more places The trains are pretty clean and almost always run regularly and on time One downside is that like most of Bangkok it's not very handicap or suitcase friendly I think most of the station's lifts are out of order So you'll have to use either an escalator (usually one on either side of a station) or walk up the stairs

The BTS Skytrain is in good company in Bangkok with the MRT Underground Train  both provide public transport at a world class standard  If you're staying within close proximity to one the stations of either service they should be your primary transport whilst in Bangkok  if you're not staying within close proximity I suggest you should consider relocating   If the Skytrain doesn't get you to one of the mustsee attractions around Bangkok the MRT likely will  and viceversa  Skytrain offers the views of BKK whilst perched above the ground in airconditioned comfort but MRT stations provides a reprieve from the heat whilst waiting for air conditioned trains to come along   Skytrain and MRT each have an interchange station with the Airport Train to and from the basement of Suvarnabhumi Airport  again a great world class service that gets you as close to the airport as a taxi does  I'm also a huge fan of this train service (cheap very reliable and avoids horrendous traffic) and there's another airport link being constructed at the moment (Sep 2016) to service BKK's other major airport at Don Mueang

reviewTitle: Travel across the city couldn't be easier.
reviewText: The nearest station was only 8 mins away from our hotel BTS is a great traffic buster You can spend hours in a taxi queuing whereas the BTS gets you around most parts of the city really quickly We bought a day pass each which was approx ¬£5 for the 2 of us or you can get single journeys for as little as ¬£030 Queue at the ticket desk either for change for the tickets machine or to purchase a day pass The stations work like the London Underground just make sure you know which line (one of 2) and where the terminal station is so you get the right train All the stations are numbered Make sure you know the name of the station at your destination and look up its number on the machine Select the number and it tells you how many coins to put in All in english and very simple Its not as wide spread as the London Underground but between the BTS and the MRT (Underground) you can cover most of the city

reviewTitle: WOW! What a ride. The BTS rocks.
reviewText: I am an American world traveler for decades   I am sure I have experienced over 100 mass transit system around the world My rating system is simple and ingrained to memory evaluation for acceptability in this order (1) possibility of personal danger (2) safety from mechanical failure and human failures (3) fear factors of any other rare source (4) comfort (5) secondary and EVEN unfathomable fear factors (6) a distant last concern of efficiency and price  Simply put the BTS rates the highest in all categories of all the world's mass transportation systems Crime of any sort is almost nonexistent   Trains are comfortable bright colored people are friendly helpful polite generous and very protective of foreigner's safety and happiness I promise   No guns no knives no drinks no food no problem are the rules of the trains   Above ground trains are called BTS trains and underground trains are called MRT All the same in my rating scale  I welcome you you to Bangkok Average BTS or MRT ride is less than 50 cents  Welcome aboard

This is a very efficient way of travel in central Bangkok The trains are very frequent & spotlessly clean The train is very well air conditioned which can be very comfortable in a normal hot day in Bkk Travellers on the Skytrain are required not to eat or drink in transit the Thais observe this rule meticulously however occasional tourists do not perhaps through ignorance Most people know that traffic in Bkk can be very heavy this is certainly the case in peak hours before 10 am & again building up from 3pm In between these hours it is usually fine to use taxis at peak times however the Skytrain wins hands down Skytrain stations are still being built around Bangkok The oldest stations tend to be around the central area Not all of these stations have lifts however which can make things difficult for those with walking problems or travelling with prams etc as there are usually many stairs to the platformsMost stations do have moving stairs upwards ( but not always downwards) so do look around for these if you need this assistance There is a very good system for queuing at Skytrain stations follow the arrows on the platform or observe the Thai people & do as they do The Skytrain is no cheaper than taking a taxi & more expensive if there are several of you travelling There are ticket machines at the station & desks where you can obtain change for the machines Street & station maps help you to know how much the ticket will cost from your start point to destination Even if you do not need to use the train while in Bkk one journey will be an interesting experience

reviewTitle: Convenient, fast, and safe transportation system
reviewText: Each time I come back to Bangkok I'm impressed with how efficient and convenient the BTS Skytrain system is They have extended it and linked it with the Airport Rail Link along Sukhumvit so that one can  theoretically at least  travel by transit from the city to Suvarnabhumi Airport The BTS Skytrain system is beautifully integrated with the city of Bangkok in a way that adds to the city's character Some stretches of the Skytrain system function almost as fairly temperate elevated walkways above the hot city streets The stretch of track from Siam Paragon to the National Stadium is a case in point The only complaint I have about the BTS Skytrain is the lack of weekly 3day or 2day travel Sky train passes These would be a boon to many visitors to Bangkok Right now if a tourist wants to take multiple trips on the Sky train he must buy an expensive 120 baht 1day pass which expires by at midnight

reviewTitle: Convenient and ever expanding transport vehicle!
reviewText: We go to Thailand since 1999 and we just missed the official inauguration at that time Since it's service is up and running we've been using this transportation vehicle at least a few times each holiday While it's a great way to move around in certain parts of Bangkok it could get quiet pricey if you're travelling with 3 or more persons It could be cheaper by taxi though there are no traffic lines  What we noticed during recent years is that not only during rush hour it is getting overcrowded now I strongly suggest the BTS service to add extra trains to the schedules It's nice to see Bangkok from an upper floor passing by And what I miss the most since we're back in Holland are the food stalls at every exit Those fruits and sates are sooo delicious During the last holiday we stayed at Centara Grand Central World Plaza and we did not need to use the skytrain at all But we did use the skywalk many times This is the walking way between the ground floor roads and the Skytrain track So choosing a bit more expensive hotel could save you costs of transportation if you like to be in the area of Siam Square What I recommend people who travel to Thailand for the first time is right after arrival taking the Skytrain from a nearby station to Saphan Taksin From there take the Express Boat on the Chao Phraya river If the weather is ok you could even get off at Pier Wat Mahathat and enter the Grand Palace This way you might scratch it from your todo list immediately and inside the Grand Palace it's also very relaxed Right after this visit take the boat and skytrain back to your hotel for a diner in that area I guarantee a very nice first day using multiple transportation vehicles and you'll get familiar with how to use these as well  If you're about to use the skytrain a lot ask for special cards at the Helpdesks located nearby the entry of the BTS

reviewTitle: Very good way to get around the city
reviewText: Bangkok BTS or also known as skytrain for its elevated tracks is the best way to move around within the big metropolis of Bangkok   Most tourist attractions and major shopping malls are either directly connected to or within a short walk from a BTS station  Best to stay at a hotel within the vicinity of a BTS Station as you will not waste precious time as a tourist getting stuck in the notorious Bangkok traffic jams   There are current 2 lines which are the Silom line and Sukhumvit line and both interchange at Siam Station There are also a few interchange with the newer underground MRT  The coaches itself are clean with strong air conditioning which is a relieve in hot afternoons in Bangkok

Very fast we will reach your destination faster than using tuktuk or taxi due to traffic mainly during day time If you want to save time and money use the BTS Skytrain

reviewTitle: Clean, organized but needs English speaking locals
reviewText: very accessible and organized transpo system but we had a hard time communicating with the locals on some things we need clarification of But overall we love how modern their train system is

reviewTitle: Convenient and time saving pleasurable transport alternative in Bangkok's most infamous traffic.
reviewText: BTS Skytrain along with MRT underground train have made travelling in Bangkok more bearable Now that the BTS system has extended on both ends across Bangkok to Thonburi side and also along Sukhumvit to the out skirt of Bangkok travelers have better chances to reach their destinations and their business appointments on time than using other means of transportation  The trains are also well maintained and spotlessly clean and completely safe Highly recommend for visitors to try

reviewTitle: most convenient public transport in Bangkok
reviewText: The train is good if you're in hurry and don't want to find a parking space at your destination but it could get very very very crowded during rush hour and as Bangkok is a warm city you can expect smell and sweat

reviewTitle: Can be crowded, but good way to travel.
reviewText: Fast effective means of travelling stops are centered around the main shopping areas which makes it easy to travel  Limited stops can get hot waiting for the train as you may have to wait for more than 1 especially at Siam Beware stairs and not escalators
Good fast cheap I used it instead of taxi or tuc tuc that are not good for the Bangkok traffic Use it
The skytrain works great it is safe and reliable Signs and voice announcement are both in thai and in English and employees are most helpful even when don't speak much English

Have you serious  trains in different metropolitan cities such as Washington DC  Paris  But I truly love the SkyTrain in Bangkok because it is one of the simplest Transportation medium to use    You look at the map and the circles at your stop will tell you exactly how how much money you need to get to your destination there is no guessing what's so ever    It does get pretty full and sometimes you do have to wait more than one train to get any if it is after 4 or 5 in the afternoon    I love the BTS

Cabin are fairly clean One of the best way to get around the city without being caught in a jam Fares are affordable as well Signages are also pretty clear making it easy to travel around Walkways under the train track are able a innovative feature to get from point to point without being exposed to the hot sun
Easy and fast Also cheap for european prices Take the skytrain to Saphan Taksim and then take the publicboat to the innercity

Efficient fast cheap and a fast if you wanna avoid traffic jams in Bangkok When travelling to the airport the skytrain was a little crowded We had to wait in line which is a good thing and missed some skytrains This wasn't a problem as there were suddenly 3 trains in 10minutes

PORS Easy access to many main attractions in Bangkok Not affect by crazy ground traffic   CONS Not cheap compare to Uber or taxi if u have 2 or more people Sky train entrance from the ground mostly required to take long stairs Stops quite long time in some stops

Staff speak excellent english to purchase ticket   Maps easy to understand trains run frequently during the day very comfortable and air conditioned  Best way to travel from the river to the shopping centres at MBK and Siam
Hot tip At Siam station make sure you listen and read There is one track for two different directions at the station So make sure you get on the correct train
Best is to purchase a day or 2 pass It is easiest and fastest and the cheapest way to travel to all the malls and the temples One also gets the see the city while travelling

reviewTitle: Best choice to get around the city
reviewText: As a solo traveler familiar with public transportation is a necessity to get around  In bangkok rail transportation or BTS is quite easy to learn They provide English language services so that foreign tourists can learn Helps to easily reach several interesting places in the city of Bangkok without being exposed to traffic jams  But since this is public transportation it is used in conjunction with the local people so that at a certain hour will be very crowded However BTS remains the best choice for the travelers can enjoy the city
Reaching different places in bangkok was made easy by travelling in skytrain instead of travelling in other modes which gets stuck in heavy traffic

reviewTitle: Best mode of Transport in Bangkok
reviewText: Considering the high amount of traffic in the streets this is the best way to get around Don't do the same mistake I didDon't hop into a taxi during the rush hour anywhere between 3 pm to 8 pm it will take ages to go from one place to another It took us almost 3 hours just to go from our Westin hotel to Baiyoke Sky tower which is normally a 30 min ride  The BTS Skytrain is very fast and efficient with trains coming every 5 minutes and riding them is fun as you get to see all kinds of people from all over the world  The only problem is the ticketing system in our station (Asok) was a bit troublesome as it used the outdated coin system And the stations had no aircon which was a bummer if you waiting in the daytime when it's very hot and humid

Limited routes only take you to some places It was cheap and frequent A bit annoying to have to carry change for the machine I queued up at the ticket counter a couple of times and they just gave me change for the machine   they didn't sell me a ticket   Although taxis are cheap the traffic can get congested so it's a good alternative so long as it takes you where you want to go   I used it to get to the Central Ferry Pier which was good and Asoke where there is a lot of nightlife
This is a great way to see Bangkok Easy to use and cheap No waiting as train comes every few minutes

The BTS has revolutionised travel around Bangkok Cannot say what the line out to Suvarnabhumi Airport is like but around the city the skytrain is a cool life saver  New since we were last there were safety barriers added to reduceprevent people toppling onto the train tracks Good idea  Purchasing tickets is relatively painless with operators speaking reasonable English  Skytrain maps are at every station so no chance of getting lost  The air conditioning is a wonderful break in the heat of exploration around a vibrant city

reviewTitle: Unless you wanna walk till you drop.... use the BTS!
reviewText: Clean efficient and frequent  like it's "below the ground" counterpart the BTS is a brilliant way to get to almost anyplace in Bangkok
Use it over taxis when you can Well air conditioned and clean Busy during peak times Safe for solo travelers

reviewTitle: Traffic worse than NYC - You must use BTS
reviewText: There was a BTS station one block from our hotel Sign are in Thai and English and easy to follow Basically this is a east West North south system with a major hub The cars are air conditioned and very smooth There are lines at rush hour but everyone is very orderly The street traffic in Bangkok is so bad that using this system is a must and it's is efficient
BTS skytrain is the best way to get around Bankok The trains run very frequently  So easy to use a day pass  is cheapest way to go Get on and off all day no limit

The BTS Skytrain was so easy to take and also very cheap It was also excellent because it's air conditioned If you can get to your destination on the Skytrain I would definitely recommend it over a cab

reviewTitle: Great way to avoid the traffic
reviewText: Very clean and easy to use I'm from St Louis and rode the metro frequently and I can't even compare the two because the BT's was very well maintained

reviewTitle: Best way to get around Bangkok
reviewText: While it can get pretty crowded in rush hour the trains run efficiently and are very reasonable if you buy a pass  I spent a week and a half and used it daily to commute from my hotel to our office  Signs and announcements are also in English so it's easy for a visitor to get around

A fast way of transportation if you want to go across Bangkok Quite modern trains that are air conditioned Prices on medium level Total network is limited since you can not reach the historic part of Bangkok by BTS

We took the skytrain to the Princess Hotel at the MBK Was very exciting and EXTREMELY crowded due to rush hour Easy to use and fun for the kids but would no way call this an "attraction" rather an easy way to get around the city

reviewTitle: Cheapest & Fastest way to move around in Bangkok
reviewText: 1 User friendly ticket machine in every station 2 Staff at station is very courteous & they speak good English 3 Fares are quite cheap when compared to using Tuk Tuk or cabs But again Skytrain is the best option if you have to reach a particular destination with a particular time in mind 4 Security personnel have a stylish & respectful way of treating commuters I was returning from MBK mall with goods in my hand Security person checked my bag and saluted me stylishly for allowing her to check my bag I truly admired her way of handling people In return I thanked her for doing her job so well 5 Maps and directions are well planned and put up everywhere to make life easier for commuters

reviewTitle: Quick, cheap and excellent air conditioning!
reviewText: For a tourist the BTS (and the Metro) get you to most places you need to go without having to haggle with taxi drivers who won't turn on meters  Been using the BTS for years and it is so quick  almost cathartic speeding above the city looking at the traffic gridlock below  The aircon is out of this world on a hot and sticky day

I only wish North American urban transit could catch up with Bangkok Kuala Lumpur and Singapore  We travelled daily with a 13 year old daughter and sixteen year old son  Safe clean and much much much faster than the clogged roads

This doesn't take you everywhere you need to get to but it can get you close the MRT is accessible from certain stops  We made it around Bangkok with tuktuk taxi BTS MTR and the river long tail boats  Not as good as London but still a great way to get around
The fastest and cheap way of getting around Bangkok's busy downtown section BTS connect to many bus stops train station malls and many great locations of interest
Bangkok otherwise is very jam packed but traveling is quick through bts  Keep maps handy and you can travel very easily  Neat stations do not dirty them
Beautiful train Super fast Enjoyed my travel from Asoke to MBK mallWould appreciate cleanliness in train and station
Although the Skytrain doesn't cover the whole of Bangkok it is still a good clean and efficient way of getting around avoiding the incessant Bangkok traffic It is also air conditioned

The traffic can be horrible in Bangkok which makes it quicker to take the BTS if you're next to one You pay the amount of baht depending on how many stops you need to go through You'll need coins but you can get that from the front desk and all tickets are purchased through an automated machine Just watch the people in front of you and it should be pretty straight forward

This is one of the best public transit systems I have been on It is very clean safe and new and I never found myself waiting more than 5 minutes for a train The ticketing system is super easy to figure out   It's fairly useful for foreigners but as of Aug 2016 there aren't many stops although this should be less of an issue by 2020
Clean safe and easy to use So much better than a tuk tuk or taxi drive just waiting to rip you off

Given that Bangkok's roads are always almost at halt during peak hours BTS and MRT are two quick ways to get away from the traffic  BTS is connected to several major stations BTS route Maps are available online and also at the back of your ticket when you purchase them There are several ticket vending machine at each station or you can even approach the ticket counters Some counters give you coins to get tickets from the vending machine The vending machines only accept coins so you do need to have enough coins As such the machines are easy to operate you just click on the station's name and they show the amount If u are more than one person it's better to go to the counter They also give a daily pass for 120 BHT and u can use it for that day (unlimited stops) But if you don't plan to drop by many stations in one day just get the tickets as you go
The cheapest and fasted way around Bangkok A much better alternative to taxis or tuk tuks Most importantly growing bigger every year

Thai BTS is a general above ground experience where trains run above the ground unlike the MRT station where the trains run undergound While the station is long the trains cabins are modest so if you stand at the end of the station you will be the lone ranger there as the train only stops at the center part of the platform  Payment is via  cash or coins If you need to change a little coins with a huge note eg 1000b just queue at the station control and the person inside will change it for you The tourist pass is now (Sept 2016) per day so it is not quite a great deal unlike a three day  pass or sth  The BTS used to be quite leisurely where only expatriates and tourists pay for it However in this trip the train appears to be fully packed at different times of the day and there are occasions where passengers cannot squeeze in

reviewTitle: Fast Modern Service Above the Traffic Jams

reviewText: Very convenient cheap and comfortable train which covers most of the city   The people of Bangkok think it gets busy but if you have done a London Tube at rush hour you'll think Bangkok rush hour is a treat  I recommend getting a rabbit card (pay as you go card) saves the queues

I really recommend the BTS to move around Bangkok It is easy to get to know safe fast cheaper and crossing main areas Taxis are really unsafe with some drivers behaving really rude and corrupt (no using taximeters or altering it denying service etc) Tuktuk service is only for short distances and motorbike services for distances as far as 2 kilometers  I would look at the nearest station to the place I would need to go then I would take a motorbike to end the travel if it is a little far from that station  Bangkok people are really friendly in the stations including the security personnel you just show them the station (if English is a problem) and they are always kind to indicate You get the ticket in the box office or the machine choose the station that has a number that is the cost and put that number of coins and ready

This is the life saver in KrungthepJust a decade or so ago Bangkok is infamous for its heavy traffic jams Today this city works beautifully thanks to this great transport infrastructure The BTS has taken me to many parts of Bangkok ChinaTown EM Quartier Silom Siam Square and Asoke just to name a few It's convenient and hassle free Just buy the store value Rabbit Card as you would the Foodcourt card in Terminal 21 and you can rock and roll in Bangkok Happy station hopping

reviewTitle: good tariff rate and for easy transport

reviewTitle: Best way to Travel around the City
reviewText: BTS skytrain is very easy to use for tourist like us The ambiance is great and very spacious though you have to know that it gets very crowded during rush hour but all in all I love their transportation system and the people here are very helpful too
Extremely easy to use with everyone at the station and locals being really helpful when required And cheap too

You can get everywhere across the city so easily I actually will only ever choose a hotel that is next to a BTS station  Although it does take a couple of times to get used to connecting with the MRT and other lines it is by far the fastest and most comfortable way to get around Bangkok  Watch out for the doors (don't fight with them they will always win)

We used the BTS regularly buying a day ticket meaning we could travel day or night and we did I especially love the orderly system of lining up whilst waiting for the train waiting till all passengers alighted and then we streamed in efficiently Not the push and shove and coas I have experienced in New York mind you I love it all  It was easy to get to any destination even with train and platform changes and when unsure someone was there to help  With the recent bombings in Bangkok they now have security checking bags when entering the main stations not all that thorough but I did find that made a sense of comfort for me I don't remember these check point years ago so I assumed it was because of the recent events  Go ahead live like the locals use the BTSin fact one day we were in a Tuk Tuk and crawling and at a standstill in peak hour traffic that we jumped out of the tuk tuk as we right next to the station and got on the train back to our hotel cooler quicker and less flustered

The BTS Skytrain is a convenient way to travel around Bangkok  As the network is extended covering more and more areas It is probably one of the best mode of transport to travel  The bridges built connecting the stations and shopping centre has made it very easy to walk from one area to the others without having to cross the road  The disadvantage is that all the stations are built without enclosure so no air condition is provided This could get very uncomfortable when the humidity is high  The other downside is that all the stations are several storeys high and no lifts or escalators are provided in most areas making it a hard climb to the station  The structures supporting the railway track and stations seems to be so much heavier and bigger in Bangkok than for example of those in Singapore or other countries thus making it unsightly   Other than that its a good transport system
its cheap and fast kinda uncomfortable during peak hours as it tends be really crowded otherwise its great for travelling within the city if you're on a budget trip
Excellent service we use it all the time  cheap clean on time convenientair conditioned can be very busy at times but next one arrives very quickly just brilliant service

reviewText: The Skytrain is very easy to use air conditioned and quick However it is so crowded at certain hours that it makes harder to use with smaller kids If you're on vacation you may want to plan your day to get around rush hour (mainly when high school students commute in and out of school)

reviewText: If are leaving from near a station and going to a destination near another station it is the best way to travel Fast Cheap and reasonably comfortable if you avoid peak travel times   Yes rainy weather is a drag but many destinations have covered access but if not you may have to wait in a sheltered area Anyway if it's pouring ground traffic grinds to a halt  so you are better off anyway  So as far as possible book a hotel near a station eg Grand Hyatt or St Regis and try and pick restaurants that are close to a station   I have been a convert for years

reviewTitle: Easy, cheap and fast way to get around Bangkok
reviewText: The BTS is an easy way to get around Bangkok quickly in air conditioned comfort In the early morning and late afternoon beginning and ending of the work days it can be somewhat crowded but the rest of the time it is the best way to see a lot of Bangkok both on and off the train There are two different lines that run throughout BKK The Silom Line gets you down to the Chow Pri River and the Sukhumvit Line which takes you to large shopping areas and the famous Jim Thompson House Gardens and Restaurant The BTS is safe inexpensive clean and easy to use with signs in English

reviewTitle: Very reliable... will even keep you out of the heat!
reviewText: As I was born and bred in Tokyo I know how a metro system should work Yes Bangkok's BTS Skytrain System is still small in comparison but its a good start At present they have the Silom and Sukhumvit Lines running The trains are clean cool and reliable Can get busy during rush hour but tolerable At least you're not being probed in the back by a station employee like in Tokyo Ha Fares are based on distance (like in Tokyo) but are relatively cheap ex Siphon Taksin Station to Siam Station is 34 Bahts Rather than taking the taxi through rush hour traffic (which is horrendous) why not try the BTS Skytrain

reviewTitle: One of the best public transport systems I've ever used
reviewText: The BTS line is an excellent and cheap way of exploring Bangkok We stayed right beside National stadium which is the one of the terminus stations on the Silom Line The BTS is split into two lines the Silom and Sukhumvit lines with both lines intersecting at Siam where you can chop and change It also interlinks with the ARL (airport rail line) at Phaya Thai BTS station for those wanting to use the BTS ARL to get back to the airport If you're going to be on and off the BTS through the day for exploring the city I would recommend purchasing a 1 day unlimited use pass for 140baht (around ¬£220) whereas shorter journeys can cost as little one way as 35 baht (40p) The carriages are all airconditioned and provide a welcome relief from the Bangkok heat and humidity For areas the BTS can't reach there are frequent connections with the MRT underground line For a cheap clean and excellently reliable way of exploring Bangkok and getting from A to B I cannot recommend enough the BTS We could learn a lot from this back in the UK

reviewTitle: Fast but don't bring a child buggy
reviewText: So much better cheaper faster than any other mode of transport in Bangkok Really easy to use The only thing I'd say is they need more escalators carrying child buggy up and down stairs was not much fun Still it was like riding the future

I purposely chose a hotel near the BTS to be able to get around easily especially at peak travel times when you could see traffic at a stand still  It's true that the trains were busy during those times but it was better to stand for a few stops than be stuck in gridlock in a taxi  And even more I was happy to avoid the tuktuks and their tricky detours whenever I could It was a wonderful system with clearly marked stops and very useful signs directing you to your destination at every station  I purchased a card so that I wouldn't need to get change for each ride and would highly recommend that if you have a few days in Bangkok  There's also the option for a day pass but I found this less useful as it doesn't apply to the other types of transport (MRT ART river boats)

I took the rot fai fa to get to Siam Paragon (the mall)  We discovered a starbucks at the Paragon which was the most wonderful thing to see when you can't find decent coffee in Thailand  We bought extra large coffees to go but when we tried to get back on the train they wouldn't let us  Half of us were on one side of the turnstile and the other half with our coffees were on the other side  The guard was very rude and wouldn't allow us on  So my husband GULPED his coffee burning hot right then and there  It was a terrible experience especially since the rot fai fa charges high prices to ride it  For the average thai this is not a normal mode of transportation  My Thai family made an exception for us to ride it so that we could experience it   Overall it's a beautiful train with stops at good locations But in the future I probably will not take it

reviewTitle: Best way to travel within Bangkok
reviewText: The BTS Skytrain is the perfect way to travel within Bangkok Connecting over 50 kms of area the 2 train lines (Sukhumvit and Silom lines) connect at Siam interchange station making it easy to get to any part of the city  You can also connect to the underground MRT train line at Asok station or to the Airport rail link at the Phya Thai station  Fares start at 15 baht up to a maximum of 40 baht  This is also a great way to see the city from above  Tip Avoid taking the train at peak hours as it gets to be very crowded with office workers  You should also purchase a prepaid card so that you don't have to join the long queue to get your tickets

reviewTitle: Probably the best way to move around Bangkok
reviewText: Bangkok is huge and is always busy no matter the day or the hour Therefore moving around by taxi car or bus is quite a nightmare So the Sky Train once it moves above the traffic jams is probably the best way to move all over Bangkok It's cheap has aircon and is relatively fast By the other hand one may find it also good to have a different view over Bangkok

This skytrain is a dream from the airport (which is an impressive one itself)  For $150 US and very helpful staff (maybe America can learn a thing or two) you ride a comfortable clean modern train to stops in the city that connect to buses taxis and subways Announcements in Thai and English spotless and painless  By comparison a taxi (even if you are not ripped off) on the highway ran me $21 at off peak times and can go higher  Still a bargain compared to NY
Safest way to travel around Bangkok  Maximum fare is 40THB  Air conditioned  Fairly busy Easy navigation

reviewTitle: Not an attraction but gets you to places quickly
reviewText: I don't understand why this is an attraction because it is simply a means to get you places It is definitely better than the London underground being cooler and with some views but can still get very busy  Quicker than a taxi due to the Bangkok traffic if it covers the area you want to go

reviewTitle: What a Great Way to Get Around
reviewText: Easy cheap safe and convenient way to get around the city   We enjoyed using it as much for the experience as for getting to places like Siam Paragon and MBK Shopping Centres   You buy tickets from the ticket machines Staff do not sell ticks over the counter Machines only take coins not notes but staff at the booths will exchange your notes for coins if you need  Once you‚Äôve got your coins go to the ticket machine select your fare code by reference to the useful station map you‚Äôll find stuck to the machine itself insert your coins and out comes your ticket It‚Äôs that easy Use the tickets to go through the barrier and then come out again at your destination There are a some daily and weekly ticket options but we just bought single tickets as needed as they are so cheap ‚Äì about 20 THB per trip But just be aware that Thailand suffers from hyperinflation so these prices are only valid as at Aug 09 and will probably have gone up by the time you travel  You‚Äôll find staff at the staions helpful and polite  Don‚Äôt hesitate to use this form of transport as much as you can Especially in a gridlocked place like Bangkok it‚Äôs the best way to get around Just be aware though that at peak times in early morning late afternoon they get very full

reviewTitle: Convenient travel if it's not during People going to work or leaving work, the car is very comfortable.
reviewText: BTS is a convenient and fast way to travel in Bangkok It is a good choice for avoiding traffic problems and real road taxes (except rush hour)
The best way to get around BKK Easy to use very cheap and a frequent service Very modern and clean Can get a bit overcrowded at rush hour but that's to be expected
BTS AND MRT are best  way to get tourist location visit around us fast and easy and there very Helpfull in tickets counter so in Bangkok use Metro üöá
Very comfortable and My favorite way to go around the city easier than others Time save a lot and feel convenience
The most comfortable method for travel around the whole city Prices and services are reasonable Saving time is a big advantage
Comfortable no traffic jam and can go many famous place This is the best way as public transportation There is no doubt about its useful

reviewTitle: BTS is clean, simple, inexpensive and fast
reviewText: Although it can get crowded at peak times the BTS is the best method of travel in Bangkok if it matches with your destination It is very simple to buy tickets using the kiosks (which can show English easily) or the ticket agent at the window The trains are clean air conditioned and run fairly frequently

reviewTitle: best way to get around Bangkok
reviewText: It just works The service is inexpensive the trains are clean punctual and of course airconditioned
If there's an option to take MRT Take MRT instead BTS is a bit pricey MRT is the faster as well compared to BTS

The Skytrain was our preferred transportation for touring Bangkok  It was speedy highly efficient and low cost  Quiet trains with comfortable seats and provided access to most major shopping malls and other famous destinations in Bangkok

After living in Vancouver Canada and experiencing the Skytrain and also having been to New York City I would say the BTS is extremely good It is fast clean has very good AC (much needed after walking around in Bangkok) is simple to use and very cost friendly It costs about 40 THB or about $2 CDN to go 6 stops All stations are fully covered to keep you protected from the wicked rainstorms All stations have large thermo scans to take everyone's temperature before entering (due to COVOD19) and it is mandatory for everyone to wear a mask (and they have staff to enforce it)

Probably the easiest way to get around although not the most comfortable particularly at peak times Journeys are certainly quiet as most passengers are concentrating on their mobile phones It's useful to have some change when buying tickets but be prepared for quite long queues at the machines and ticket offices Prices are very reasonable Within the carriages are some priority seats for the elderly pregnant or those who with very small children However it seems that many students in Bangkok cannot read given that in the carriages we travelled in all these seats were occupied by young people who studiously ignored anyone with a legitimate claim to a priority seat Using the rail system in Bangkok is much more preferable to going by taximuch cheaper and much quicker
As long as you live close to a BTS station then everything is fantasic  commuting wise BTS keeps a world class standard much better than e g London subway

reviewTitle: Fast, nice a/c only way to get around
reviewText: The SkyTrain is fast and will allow you to bypass the miserable traffic Single ride tickets are easy to get and there are other passes too
About the best way to get about Bangkok Cheap and once mastered easy to use Trains may be packed most of the time but taxis in traffic worse

reviewTitle: Good way to beat Bangkok traffic
reviewText: BTS Skytrains are fast frequent efficient and air conditioned The network of lines has expanded over the years so that it now covers much of the city Connection to the subway (seperate fare) gives an even longer range Cars can be crowded at peak times but not during most of the day or evening Easy connection by boat to visit hotels temples along the river and Iconsiam shopping complex (free or very cheap fare) NOTE to buy a stored value card to use on BTS you need to pay 100 bhat (about $325) and show your Passport so it can be regestered to you This is only when you first buy it and is not required to top up value later for other trips

We recently had a 10 day stay in the executive level of the Marriott Marquee Queen‚Äôs Park hotel Bangkok from 1222 October 2019  It is our second visit and we have a further visit in 2 February 2020 for 7 nights  We write to compliment your staff they were all unfailingly polite and helpful but of course we had an opportunity to get to know the staff in the executive lounge club better over ten cocktail hours and would particularly compliment Gail Eak Mu and Toon for their service               Charles Goh

Is what you expect from a transit system Clean on time and relatively hassle free Bit of a stair climb up and down from the stations and can be a bit crowded however gets you close to most of the popular places in Bangkok and is in expensive If there are a couple of you sometimes cheaper to catch a taxi but then you would have to contend with traffic

The Bangkok metro system (to include the BTS) is decent with one drawback Each train line has its own ticket systems so for example if you are transffering between the BTS and the MTR you need to go buy a new ticket Otherwise its a decent system which can get you close most places in town
Nice but crowdy Fare is not that expensive less than the popular tuktuk Best to beat the traffic out there
good mode of Transportation tickets only with coins or at counter Coverage of town could be (will be better in future) Need walk or tuktuk for last meters

It's a convenient to travel to and fro airport and city center It took less time and money than taxis No bargain needed No need to be cheated by the driver It costed us THB40 per head per adult per trip

The SkyTrain is a very useful above ground metro train linking Bangkok south to north via Siam Square the heart of modern Bangkok It is cheap and easy to use Downsides are that it gets very crowded so you often have to stand and that it is elevated so you have to walk up Sometimes there are elevators but not always where you need them Also it is an ugly monstrosity that dominates the streets it is on
Quick easy transport around parts of the city Nothing to get excited about it's a city train system

reviewTitle: Easy way to get around BKK
reviewText: Took the BTS to the King Power Building get yourself a Rabbit card at the kiosk You can reload it
It's very cheap and convenient for travelers I highly recommend to use when there is traffic Great job BKK

reviewTitle: Very cold temperature inside the train, compared to the outside
reviewText: You may want to take a sweaterscarflight jacket because if you have been walking outside for a while and then have to travel a long way the contrast in the temperature feels uncomfortable Though it is not as quick as I would want it to be it is still appeared to be a faster way of traveling than by taxi The personnel at the ticket desk speak English quite well no problem to buy the ticket (if you are buying one way ticket do not forget to return it into the slot at the exit tourniquet)
By far the easiest and fastest way around Bangkok Just beware the train does get crowed plus you can get to Metro stations and transfer over
By using bts in Bangkok you can save time as well cost  You only wait train no more than two mins   It saves your time and cost compare to other transportoin

reviewTitle: The easiest way to get around

Both the skytrain and metro are excellent means of getting around Bangkok  Clean easy to manage and inexpensive
We took a short ride from one emd to other Good view and exiting You can see the city and understand the major places better And most important you get a feel of the locals

reviewTitle: Skytrain a  great way to see the  city
reviewText: There is  an extensive  network of  public transit is  Bangkok  It  permits  one to get  around and avoid the horrendous traffic  Its  very quick and clean  We  went  from the Ratchechewi station  to Chang Erawan station in about 30 minutesIt  cost  about 60 baht

This train connects to the train fromto airport to various locations within Bangkok I was looking for ticket for the whole day for my conveniencebut did not find any such ticket I expected maps with important places marked and closest skytrain station marked but did not find it the stations only had the skytrain maps The only saving grace was the information center who attend to you in English Tre skytrain is comfortable and seems well connected provided you know which place is close to which skytrain station

reviewTitle: Nice way to avoid car traffic jams
reviewText: As of now there are still few lines operating Two main city lines one to the airport and another one from the suburbs But many are under construction The two main traditional lines so called Sukhumvit and Silom lines intersect in Siam Another one goes to the airport with a few stops in between The connection is fairly easy  cross the platform if you change for a train going in the same direction  change floors if you are going in the opposite direction Trains are air conditioned and very well equipped in terms of handles or bars to hold on Each station is announced at least two times on the speaker system  The problems are that it can get overly crowded at rush hours The lines were extended 4 years ago going into the suburbs It took close to a year to go from 3 to 4 cars per train One line got extended again and there are still 4 cars whereas the platform could accommodate 6 No consideration for the customer  Price is steep Students get a break but extremely small Senior citizens also get a break but only Thai nationals   If two or more persons are travelling a taxi is more than likely cheaper and will take you door to door  Overall a great way to move around if on a schedule but would require a change in management to a more consumercustomer oriented staff

Great way to get around Bangkok nice clean and reliable Has Air con on the train itself and lots of maps to explain where you are and where you are going  Very easy to use similar to London Underground Great views as you are travelling and lots of windows to see the whole of Bangkok
The in itself superior skytrain is losing customers simply because they can not get in Reverted to MRT instead but that is not an option for all destinations however  Please BTS make te trains longer

Does what it says on the tin  very simple and quick way to travel round the city We found taxis were about the same value for a family of four travelling short distances but by skipping the traffic this was far more relaxed Easy selfexplanatory ticket purchase and very easy to follow route maps and station call outs Believe you can save time and money by buying pay as you go tickets in advance

reviewTitle: A great and affordable mode of transport right in the heart of Bangkok
reviewText: There is no better way to get around Bangkok as it could take over an hour to move 1km in the city by car at any given time of the day It's safe It's reasonably inexpensive It's clean Its fast & efficient What more cpuld a traveller ask for

reviewTitle: Great Way to Travel, However Many Steps!
reviewText: For travelling it is an option however some stations do not have escalators  so many steps to climb to get to or from the train Very crowded during peak times and rarely the opportunity to get a seat  The distance to get to a station versus hailing a cab üöï needs to be calculated  If you are claustrophobic this is not for you during peak times
First time using the sky train Was very easy to use and the ticket staff are most helpful Will use this again in the future

cool acclean on time You should spare time if you take bts during79 am working day coz super crowd and no space for backpack or big luggageBTS is not allowed to keep backpack on your back in crowd condition
A goid alternative to taxi and tuk ruk Sometimes very crowded No chance to buy a ticket at machines with paper bills It could be felt as to cold Other might enjoy the cooling down f a while
Good service to opt for slightly expansive though But you don't have more options as Taxi's are more expensive

We used the BTS train a couple of times and found them to be really reliable and efficient  Being from Australia we're used to trains that are late heavily graffitied and unsure where the doors will end up at the platform  Well Bangkok's BTS trains are the opposite  they arrive on time they are clean and they even have the spots to stand on the platform AND the train actually stops in the right spot  And very cheap to use too

reviewTitle: Good way to travel in Bangkok
reviewText: Modern aircon trains with added stations (recently) to cover most of the tha√Ø capital Need to buy single tickets at each station (lw price) Downside often crowded with people need to stand and wear your backpack in front of you Check local station to see the latest opened stations and access to main tourist attractions (indications are usually good)

reviewTitle: Excellent trip on the BTS that saves time and money!
reviewText: I‚Äôve always preferred to travel by skytrains in countries that have a great system with up to date networks that save a lot of time and money The BTS in Bangkok is just amazing and I had used it over 20 times during the 1 month I stayed in Bangkok as a tourist Definitely recommend it to everyone going to Bangkok
Amazing experience You will never get lost here as everyone speaks English Very inexpensive saves you time as during the day there is a terrible traffic on the highway

reviewTitle: First class public transport in Bangkok
reviewText: My wife and I are here for a short weekend vacation via BKK airport and staying at Asia Hotel Plan to visit the usual tourist landmarks (not the temples and palaces though because we have plenty of that in Malaysia too üòÖ) So we know that Bangkok's traffic is the worst in the world we opt to use BTS here We bought a Rabbit Card (prepaid card that can be reloaded) through Klook Costs us 200 baht We used it to go around Bangkok All main shopping mall has its own stop As for Chatuchak Weekwnd Market we can go off at Mo Chit and it's just a short walk And we also use BTS to go to Asiatique Riverfront Just take the south line BTS from Siam or National Stadium to S6 Saphan Taksin And there will be a free Asiatique shuttle ferry there (the clearly marked red long boat) For Sukhumvit line all 5 first stops are at a shopping mall such as Siam Paragon Central World Nana Terminal 21 So expect a very large crowd on BTS To take ARL to the airport the interchange is at Phaya Thai stop
It seems only has a relatively limited number of routes but they work very well One goes straight to the MBK department store best choice for food and gift bargains in bangkok bar none

reviewTitle: The best Way to go in town!
reviewText: The best public Transport to go in townYou can reach to the center in 20 minuteBut it is very busy and  full in rush hour
Easy convenient cool good temperature clean punctual new smart elevator connecting to all part of bkk
easy to use not expensive Cuts the traffic jams Air conditioned Should have more lines for better coverage
Very busy and a little expensive With little info on where to go once you arrive at a stop The staff were blunt and not friendly at all
Skytrain is the quickest cheapest and easiest way to travel in the center Just remember to check which line and right direction

We travelled from Phuket to Bangkok and used this service to Nana where our hotel was We were BTS virgins and had 3 suitcases It was rush hour and busy but we still managed to get on board without any hassle

Although the track is limited I understand that they are planning to expand It is very fast cheap and easy to get around The staff are helpful if you don‚Äôt speak the language Security is high but that is to be expected A rabbit card will get you on the bus or sky train Load the card then keep travelling

We bought "rabbit"card from the Bts ticket office and loaded an additional 100 bahts for the usage of the sky train (normal cost per station approximately 19 bahtsThe bts is very user friendlyit literally shows you where you are and what is the next stationFor example if you are in Nana station in Sukhumvit then it will be E3 and one can basically see which station to drop off or get one via the Bts mapHighly recommended especially because of the bangkok traffic and also it is airconditionedThe ticket sellers are generally quite proficient in english
The biggest difficulty in Bangkok is traffic jam If you don't have time I recommend traveling by BTS The price is higher than the bus but it is quite convenient to go to the center of city

Biggest plus point is you beat the traffic This alone is incentive for me to take the skytrian on my every visit to Bangkok Add to the fact that if you travelling alone or as a couple its an cheaper option too  If there are more of you then i guess you split the cab fare and that works out well too for a local twist you can  try the Tuk Tuk as well Other than the distance to and from the station I see no reason why not to travel by the sky train

reviewTitle: Excellent, easy and convenient way to travel
reviewText: The sky train is a great way to get around Bangkok and avoid being stuck in horrible traffic jams The train system is very easy to figure out If you are going to be in Bangkok for several days recommend buying a rabbit at station and loading money on card so you don‚Äôt have to go to kiosk every time you get on sky train You will need to have passport to purchase card this is new for security purposes Highly recommend moving around Bangkok this way

reviewTitle: Another choice of travel mode in Bangkok
reviewText: The lines are now expanding and cover more of outer Bangkok So it's quite a good choice to travel in Bangkok Avoid the rush hours and you will find it a very convenient way to travel
Although you can buy tickets from a machine you can also get them easily from the kiosk Maps are simple to follow Very crowded but organised
The proximity to our hotel was perfect  Use of the skytrain to get around is a must  So easy and fast
Perfect to hop around Use a smartphone with a local sim card and you can go wherever you want in Bangkok Also good for going from and to the airport

Once I got the hang of this good train system I was sorted travelling around Just walk up to the window and tell them what stop you are going to and get a one way ticket Normally the train was squishy so be prepared to get close to people
Sky train in BKK is a good option as traffics are so bad in BKK  Rush hour on the train is packed so be aware and ready to be a sardine

reviewTitle: Cheap and it beats the traffic
reviewText: If you need to get through the main touristy areas of Bangkok then BTS is the way to travel It does get very crowded but it's fully air conditioned to escape the heat Always carry coins as the ticket machines aren't fully updated to accept notes at all stations

reviewTitle: Very convenient way to get anywhere in Bangkok
reviewText: Taxis are so cheap it sometimes isn't worth it in groups but super quick and easy easy to get round

reviewTitle: Super convenient way to get around Bangkok

reviewTitle: Mass transit systems for Bangkok and suburbs, and will continue to be used for a long time.
reviewText: Bangkok Mass Transit SystemBangkok Mass Transit System Public Company Limited Paholyothin road Jatujak Bangkok  Mass transit has become a vital part of Thailand‚Äôs public transportation nowadays especially in Bangkok the metropolitan area   Having had an opportunity to visit the headquarters of Bangkok Mass Transit System Public Company Limited or commonly known as BTS on Paholyothin road   Being taken a good care from Mr Nattachai Pradermchit Station services manager at the station who said it‚Äôs a policy that comes directly from board of directors to consider giving a priority for passengers to become comfortable and safe when taking BTS The main goal is trying not to stop improving services for customers in all aspects   All credits go to Mister Keeree Kanjanapas  (Executive Chairman) Mister Surapong Laohaunya (CEO) Mister Sumit Srisuntithum (COO) who give guideline of operation as a work plan for staffs and officers to treat customers at the top level as if they are their family members by giving love care and respect to each other  BTS or skytrain is becoming a major route in metropolitan area and vicinity The number of passengers are increasing higher each day When the technical difficulty occurs during the operation there are technicians and well trained staffs who stand by on duty at every station to make sure everything will be solved promptly There are administrators who have been working on promoting public relations for the society in various form of activities  Importantly to all staff units who have got an assignment to do their jobs at each station Whether it be supervisors receptionists drivers janitors security guards etc They are all work as a unity in order to keep the passengers to be satisfying and sustain a prominence for the organization

reviewTitle: Really the way to beat traffic congestion
reviewText: BTS and the companion underground MRT have been terrific additions to Bangkok  They have expanded to enable travel to nearly every part of the city  fast easy and inexpensive  Most points of interest are easily walkable from one of these systems (they interchange at several points however fare cards are NOT interchangeable  Both systems have been greatly expanded and the construction outwards continues  This is good because more places are accessible but bad because passenger use is way up making trains crowded most of the time  Pros include fast frequent service low cost predictable transportation clean always most places within direct reach or a short cab ride from a station and most stations have escalators or lifts to mount the 45 stair (within a stair or two) height (or depth for MRT) if you are disabled or getting older like me  Cons are often crowded no restrooms limited seating not much directional assistance   I strongly suggest that visitors utilize the system BUT study a system map carefully before traveling  Purchase a multiuse ticket  I get a 500 baht Rabbit card (the card costs 100 (about $3 US) and the other 400 is on the card for fares  This eliminates the confusion and often long waits at ticket machines at which foreigners tend to stand and gawk  The entry gates scan the Rabbit card and display how much fare is remaining  For longer rides like to Suvernabumi Airport remember to go potty before riding  Fast air conditioned and clean  Stand near an exit so you can read the station indicator (in Thai and English) because until you get used to Thai pronunciation you won‚Äôt recognize all of the spoken station names

I have ridden on many mass transit systems throughout the United States Including Seattle San Francisco San Diego San Jose Portland Oregon Washington DC and Boston Mass Internationally I have ridden the Paris Metro and the Lille France system  That said I have experienced the highs and the lows of riding the various systems  Overall I enjoy getting to know a city via the Mass Transit system   For the 6 days we stayed in Bangkok we utilized the BTS RAIL system on a daily basis  The system is well laid out  Of course everything is generally written in Thai but there are plenty of English references    Riding the Bangkok BTS is much like many of the modern transit systems of today  You buy a chip enabled transit card  You then add value to it  Trips are based on the distance you go    To use the system you put your card by the reader  The gate opens for you to enter  At your destination you tap your card (near the reader) to open the exit gate  BTS trains are very clean  No riff raff whatsoever on these trains  They are in excellent condition and it appears the stations are all kept immaculately clean As an added plus the security near the entrance is good    If you travel to Bangkok I highly recommend using the BTS system

reviewTitle: Beat the Bangkok Traffic with a Sy Ride
reviewText: We had a week of emerging into the madness of the Bangkok traffic Turks motor bikes buses cars taxis wall to wall One day we planned to make good our escape and reach for the sky The BTS Skytrain is accessed from stairways and escalators at stations on thr route but a good starting off point is BMK department Store in the centre of town and the station is named Stadium from which you can actually see into the National Stadium The Station is well signposted but the staff are vigilant and very helpful and willing to assist you to the ticket office especially if you are standing out from the crowd as you tend to be as a tourist We went all the way to the end of the line where we were directed to alight and cross to the line on the other side all accessible with lifts escalators or stairs The return trip was comfortable air conditioned and the train filled up with people at each station The skytrain is clearly a great way to commute but is also a fun tourist activity to get away from the traffic and view Bangkok from an elevated viewpoint

reviewText: We have been coming to Bangkok for a number of years and the BTS is the best way to travel I see some reviews say there isn't enough stops in other areasmate what a complaint All you have to do is go to your nearest area then catch a tuk tuk In past years we have just put coins into a machine then punched what area we want to travel to This can be a headache especially when its busy Being a family of 5 we found it easier (especially if your staying for a week or longer to purchase a rabbit card from the ticket office Check on google what their promotion for the month is We paid 1000 baht and got two adult cards and 3 child cards and it has given us 15 trips each card Its easier to use just swipe at the starting station then swipe again at the destination station You top the card up when needed We keep our card to use next time we visit Bangkok It can get busy but thats life My kids enjoy the experience Our hotel was close to the BTS making travel easy Its totally safe too Hope this helps

reviewTitle: Convenient but often highly crowded transport network
reviewText: I‚Äôve visited Bangkok annually for 20 years and the BTS Sky Train network gets more and more crowded The platforms are built for five or six carriages but they still Only run a four carriage service which means at peak times it‚Äôs often impossible to get on the first train and you have to wait while at off peak times you‚Äôre still crammed inside which raises issues of personal space and security It is a convenient system services are regular but it is not always a pleasant journey because you‚Äôre jostling around For the elderly and those with mobility issues lifts have recently been installed at some if not all stations but road level access is only from one side of the street You need to work this into your plan There is only one escalator up to each platform and often it‚Äôs furthest from where you entered the station so look out for it There are no escalators down from the platforms so the addition of lifts is a welcome one Reasonable pricing and staff are very helpful If in doubt queue for a ticket from the staff on duty Safety doors have been added to all stations which brings some peace of mind during crowded conditions It‚Äôs a more widespread network than the underground MRT system and goes to most key tourist locations such as the Siam shopping complexes Buddha temple near the Hyatt hotel weekend market and Saphan Thaksin river terminal for boats up the river and to Asiatique night market

reviewTitle: The train system to go with in Bangkok
reviewText: Bangkok is well known for its dense traffic and traffic jams If you can avoid this by going BTS The quality of service is great A pity that it only covers a few lines

These days the  traffic in Bangkok is far better than it was in the past where just crossing a major intersection meant taking your life into your own hands and there were reports that Bankok people installed portaloos in their cars for the daily commute  However during peak hours 800  1000 am an 400  700 pm journeys that would otherwise take thirty minutes can sometimes take almost two  hours  The best way to overcome this is to head to your nearest skytrain (BTS) station Bangkok's elevated railway This mass transport system has two main lines Sukhumvit and Silom serviced by 35 stations The lines runthrough inner Bangkok to the outer suburbs in the north through  to Thon buri which is accross the river from Bangkok Together with the unerground the skytrain makes uo the Bangkok rapid transport system  If you are staying close to a BTS station a short walk or taxi journey is the way to go Bangkok has an informal inegrated public service system so If you are away from a BTS station then you should get a taxi to the closest BTS station or you  might consider going native and catch a motorcycle taxi to a bus or directly to the BTS station The stations themselves are well signposted to help you to your destination and there is usually BTS  person who will direct you although it may help to write down your destination preferrably in Thai Firstly you go to the station booth to get your change and if very lucky to get your ticket Howeveryou usually buy yor tickets from dispensing machines which show the price when you choose your destination on a screenYou proceed the the turnstyles by inserting you ticket in the slot which opens the barrier Make sure you retrieve your ticket and hurry through because they slam shut and can leave you with a nasty bruiseYou queue diagnonally to the train doors to allow people to get off and hold your ground against queue jumpers as you get on board Once aboard the clean  super chilled airconned trains have the route displayed on the wall above the doors and you will be notified in Thai and English over an intercom as you reach each station on route The fares are comparitively expensive but if you are staying for more than a day a Rabbit pass will save you heaps The journey itself is an adventure You travel above many of Bangkok's landmarks such as the Royal Bangkok Sportsclub opposite Lumpini Park and near some fine Chinese temples You can cross the river into Thonburi  It also gives you a chance to experience a cross section of Bangkok people close up on the train which you would never see from a taxi  I should mention the underground  which links the city centre with the international airport and central railway station The underground interchanges with the skytrain at Sala Dang station in Silom reviewText: BTS is the life line of Bangkok City for the locals as well as for the Tourists   The Advantage is all major malls  attractions is connected with BTS or very close proximity of BTS   Terminal 21  BTS Ashok MBK  BTS National Station Chayo Phraya River Cruise  Saphen Taksin Night Life  BTS Nana  Chatuchak Weekend Market  BTS Mo Chit Airport Rail Link (Suvarnabhumi Airport)  BTE Phaya Thai  Sky Train runs on two BTS LINES   SILOM LINE  Runs west to south between the National Stadium in the Siam shopping area and Bang Wa in Thonburi (across the Chao Phraya River) You interchange for Sukhumvit line at BTS Siam  SUKHUMVIT LINE  Runs north to east from Mo Chit to Bearing The two lines meet at Siam Station and also connect at two points with the underground (MRT) ‚Äì at Sala Daeng Station (MRT Silom) and Asok Station (MRT Sukhumvit)   Fares start at 15 baht for one stop rest check at the ticket counter or automated ticket vending machine at the the stations  Trains can get pretty full during peak hours (0700  0900 and 1600  1900)

reviewText: I am taking the BTS lines almost everyday There are two BTS lines  Sukhumvit and Silom Sukhumvit stretches from Mo Chit to Bearing or Samrong (expansion plans are work in progress) Silom Line stretches from National Stadium to Bangwa There are interconnections in some stations (ie access to MRT Airport Railway Link or BRT) In the morning the trains are quite packed It is best to take the BTS before 7am if you want to avoid the crowd Different BTS cards are available for daily or monthly (not sure if there are 3day5day passes available similar to other countries) Generally the trains are clean No food and drinks are allowed inside the station However there are food stalls around just after you pass by the exit Taking the BTS is the most convenient and most accessible way to get around Bangkok They say that condos very close to the BTS are more pricey compared to the others This makes sense When it rains or during late evenings it is safe to walk home from the BTS station It really depends on what you prefer

reviewTitle: Easy to get around but limited stations, but also very expensive
reviewText: This is not as great as many people made it out to be  The stations are limited and doesn't bring you into the heart of the city but around the outskirts  There are some stations that take you to the main shopping mall districts but if you ride from end to end prepare to spend 60 baht a person  I rode 6 stations distance with my family of 5 for 40 baht a person that came out to be 200 baht  If I took a taxi by meter it's only 100 baht  So if you have a big group the best economical way may be a taxi or uber or a van  As for the sights along the way again it's nothing  The most scenic ride is the boat ride at night up and down the Chao Paraya River  The BTS line is just dull buildings left and right with some interesting buildings afar  Bangkok definitely is not done building mass transit yet but until they do the lines available now doesn't take you to the main tourist sites  But if you are looking to hit some restaurants or shopping malls then yes this is the best way to go to avoid traffic (unless you're a big group and then cost comes into play)  Some people would say buy those 15 rides+ discount tickets  Do you really plan to do that much  Many of my group went that route and then found the lines don't really go where they want to go and end up wasting the card and at the end of the day spending more money than buying singleentry tickets

reviewTitle: Grab a good hotel map and the Skytrain will unlock your Bangkok sightseeing
reviewText: My first tip about maximising your time and energy moving around Bangkok is to choose a hotel within walking distance of a BTS Skytrain station  Then everything is fast comfortable air conditioned safe clean and easy  The different Skytrain lines link to the MTR which together will take you just about anywhere you want to go  The Skytrain also links you to the River ferry system  Trains come along every few minutes so you don't even need a timetable however be aware they do not operate 24 hours  Displays on the train and clear announcements about each stop make it easy to work out where you are and where you are going next  There is also a small map on the back of your ticket  You can get change at the counter of any station  Then head for the ticket machine and key in your destination station and the cost is displayed  Just feed your coins and your ticket and any change will appear It's inexpensive and sometimes there are cheap tickets advertised if you are going to certain destination stations   Most stations have lifts or escalators and stairs  Some busy stations are multilevel so take care to follow the signs and check you are headed in the right direction  No problems if you find you are headed the wrong way  just get off and get on another train going the right way  Some stations are always quite busy so don't expect a seat although some seats are reserved for the elderly or those with an impairment  Relax and enjoy the experience  there are some great views along the way as well
